job.name: Visdom_Service_Example
job.description: This workflow shows how to use PCA to ease deployment of service dependencies. Here, VisdomTask needs Visdom service. First, a bind_or_start_service task (Examples/5. Cloud Automation Task Templates), specifies the service we want to start, and an instance name, which is inherited by a job variable. Thus, VisdomTask can use a "endpoint" variable where service is running. Everything is handled by the previous bind_or_start_service task. Also, opening result of bind_or_start_service in a browser, you are automatically redirected your Visdom dashboard. You can also retrieve this URL from PCA portal. Once VisdomTask is finished, job goes through a Validation step so the Visdom keeps running and the user can still visualize his results. Go to the notification portal and validate to terminate the service with the task terminate_service and then the, job properly. You can share Visdom service reusing the same instance name.

So paths with spaces won't work. # Prepare Docker parameters containerName = 'activeeon/dlm3' dockerRunCommand = 'docker run ' dockerParameters = '--rm ' # Prepare ProActive home volume paHomeHost = variables.get("PA_SCHEDULER_HOME") paHomeContainer = variables.get("PA_SCHEDULER_HOME") proActiveHomeVolume = '-v '+paHomeHost +':'+paHomeContainer+' ' # Prepare working directory (For Dataspaces and serialized task file) workspaceHost = localspace workspaceContainer = localspace workspaceVolume = '-v '+localspace +':'+localspace+' ' # Prepare container working directory containerWorkingDirectory = '-w '+workspaceContainer+' ' # Save pre execution command into magic variable 'preJavaHomeCmd', which is picked up by the node preJavaHomeCmd = dockerRunCommand + dockerParameters + proActiveHomeVolume + workspaceVolume + containerWorkingDirectory + containerName else: print("Fork environment disabled")

from visdom import Visdom
visdom_endpoint = variables.get("visdom_endpoint") print(visdom_endpoint)
if visdom_endpoint is not None: visdom_endpoint = visdom_endpoint.replace("http://", "") print(visdom_endpoint)
(VISDOM_HOST, VISDOM_PORT) = visdom_endpoint.split(":")
print("Connecting to %s:%s" % (VISDOM_HOST, VISDOM_PORT)) vis = Visdom(server="http://"+VISDOM_HOST,port=int(VISDOM_PORT)) assert vis.check_connection()

task.name: Wait_For_Web_Validation
task.description: Task to pause the job and send a validation message to the notification service

script.code:
# Please fill variables notification_message = 'Please, confirm to stop the Visdom service'
# Don't change code below unless you know what you are doing from org.ow2.proactive.addons.webhook import Webhook
jobid = variables.get("PA_JOB_ID") userName = variables.get("PA_USER") schedulerURL = variables.get("PA_SCHEDULER_REST_URL")
print schedulerURL # get sessionid schedulerapi.connect()
# pause job schedulerapi.pauseJob(jobid)
# send web validation print "Sending web validation..." url = schedulerURL.replace("/rest", "") +'/notification-service/notifications' headers = '{\"Content-Type\" : \"application/json\" }' notification_content = '{\"description\": \"'+notification_message+'\", \"jobId\": \"'+jobid+'\" , \"validation\": \"true\", \"userName\": \"'+userName+'\"}' Webhook.execute('POST', url, headers, notification_content); print "Web Validation sent"
